question:
Consider the differentiable function $f:\mathbb{R}^{2}\rightarrow \mathbb{R},$ $%
f(x,y)=e^{ax^{2}+by^{2}}$. It satisfies the equations:
answer1:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2axf(x,y),
\dfrac{\partial^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4abxyf(x,y).$
answer2:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2af(x,y),\dfrac{\partial
^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4abxyf(x,y).$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2axf(x,y),\dfrac{\partial
^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4abf(x,y).$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2axf(x,y),\dfrac{\partial
^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4bxyf(x,y).$

$\begin{array}{cccc}
F: & \mathbb{R}^3 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\

\end{array}$

G: & \mathbb{R}^2 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y) & \longrightarrow & (x+y, x-2y)
\end{array}$

answer1: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)$ does not exist

Management wants to determine how many units of each product to produce so as to maximize profit. For each unit of product $1$, $1$ unit of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.

question:

x & + & 2y & = & 4 \\
x & - & 2y & = & 0 \\
4x & + & 3y & = & 12
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(2,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(\frac{24}{11},\,\frac{12}{11}\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has an infinite number of solutions of the form $\left(2y,\,y\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
How many solutions does the following linear system have, with respect to $a\in\mathbb{R}$?
$$\left\{\begin{array}{cccccccc}
ax & + & y & + & 2az & = & a+5\\
ax & - & ay & - & z & = & a\\
x & - & ay & + & z & = & 3
\end{array}\right.$$
answer1: One solution for $a\neq 1$, and no solutions for $a=1$.
answer2: One solution for $a\neq 1,-1$, no solutions for $a=1$ and infinitely many solutions for $a=-1$.
answer4: No solutions for $a\neq 0$, and one solution for $a=0$.

3x & - & y & - & 3z & - & 4w & = & 1 \\
2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{22w+7}{15},\,\frac{-7w-7}{10},\,\frac{11w+11}{30}\bigg)$ for every $w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,6,\,-2\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(3w,\,w-1,\,2w,\,w\right)$ as solution for every $w\in\mathbb{R}$.

answer1: The predictor variable is a dosage of a new drug; the response variable is the time of relief.
answer2: The predictor variable is the time of relief; the response variable is the dosage of the new drug.
answer3: The predictor variable is the mean of time of relief; the response variable is the mean of dosage of the new drug.
